by Kim Lankford
.lerome B. Schneewind,
chairman of the Philosophy
Department, gave the opening
address last week as a delegation of American philosophers
traveled to the Soviet Union to
discuss justice and liberty with
Soviet philosophers. "It was
the first time a group of
American philosphers were invited by the Institute of
Philosophy of the Soviet
Academy of Sciences," said
Schneewind.
Schneewind, who is currently teaching a class in moral
philosophy, opened the con-

ference with his address on
justice and liberty to present a
background for the discussion.
"I was asked to give a
background review of the
history of moral philosophy
and moral thought in 45
minutes," he said.
The conference, the first of
its kind, allowed the sharing the
different philosophies and served
as, "an exploratory visit with
the interests that overlapped
ours," explained Schneewind,
adding, "It is one way to
achieve mutual understanding." The topic of justice and
liberty, which was chosen two
years ago, served as the floor-

board tor discussion.
Although the Soviets' views
on justice and liberty differ
from the Americans', Schneewind found the different point
of view to be "interesting."
"They [the Soviets) follow the
Marxist and Leninist line of
thought, but they're broadening out," said Schneewind,
"They're learning American
thought and, although they
don't agree with it, they know
what we .say and teach it in
order to criticize."

Coalition Rally Celebrates Shanty Victory
by Jon Stempel
"The Coalition has not gone
bananas and hopefully has put
some sensibility in this community," said Coalition for a
Free South Africa Spokesman
Paul Genest at a Coalition
sponsored rally Friday on the
M.S.E. Lawn that ended with
the building of two shanties.
During the rally, Genest announced that Baltimore State's
Attorney Kurt Schmoke dropped the charges against the
fourteen arrested at the
September 29 protest.
The shanties that were built
during the rally were constructed on the Lower Quad
following their authorization at
an emergency session of the Executive Committee of the Board
of Trustees.
Coaliton Spokesman Patrick
Bond said at the rally that the
Coalition wanted to build two
shanties, one to "symbolize the
struggle of the South Africans," and the other "to symbolize our struggle of the last
week."
Genest said that the shanties
"provide a center for newcomers to get information.
Now that it's up we hope to
draw more people to think
about the issue and make a
move toward the Trustees."
Though the presence of shanties has thus far not swayed the
Trustees' opinion on divestment, Genest said, "There's no
question that this puts pressure
on the Trustees. It's a mental
image. They have to see it."
The shanties, constructed
where the original shanties sat
last spring, were built under
conditions set by the University
that they meet Baltimore fire
safety standards, and that they
not be staffed at night.

The rally began at 4:15 p.m.
as Genest told a crowd of
roughly 200 people, "I'm sure
everybody's aware of our
tremendous victory. This has
been an overwhelming experience, but it's been worthwhile."
Hopkins Chaplain Gretchen
van Utt then congratulated the
Coalition on its efforts but urged
that those at the rally not
become noisy out of respect for
those celebrating the Jewish
New Year in the Glass Pavilion.
Former Chaplain Chester
Wickwire followed van Utt at
the microphone, saying, "All
of us around Hopkins owe a
great deal of gratitude to what
you've done in a non-violent
way.
"All of us would like to be
thankful for Hopkins and
justice," he continued, "but
the Trustees don't always make
that easy."
Throughout Wickwire's
speech, motorists driving by
were honking their horns in
reponse to the "Honk for
Divestment" signs that the
Coalition attached to poles and
trees lining Charles Street.
"You know what that's
for," said Wickwire after a
long series of honks interrupted
his speech. "That's not for me,
I'm sure."
Wickwire also praised Joseph
H. Kaplan, a former Hopkins
student who is the presiding
judge over legal matters be. tween the administration and
the Coalition.

Money Talks: Sex Problems
Due to Perverted Lovemaps
by Jennifer Barsema
"Lovesickness is the most
common
in
illness
undergraduate and graduate
school," said Dr. John Money
at a presentation sponsored by
the Pre-Health Society on October 2. However, he assured his
listeners in the AMR I MultiPurpose Room that the sickness
almost always remits after at
most a couple of years.
Director of the • Johns
Hopkins Medical School
psychohormonal research unit,
Money is a prominant figure in
the field of sexology. His
discussion focused on the
theories explained in his book
Lovemaps. "Lovemap" is a
term coined by Money, which
he defines as "a developmental
scheme or template in the
mind/brain of the idealized
lover and projected sexuoerotic
activity." He emphasized that
an individual's lovemap is as
unique as his fingerprints.
A lovemap undergoes both
prenatal and postnatal formation and is affected by nature
and nurturing. Although a
lovemap is not completed in the

brain at birth, predilection for
masculinity or femininity exists.
The combined influences of the
skin senses, eyes, ears, and to
a lesser extent smell and taste,
finish the development.
Money explained that males
are more dependent on visual
imagery for lovemap formation, while females are more incluenced by skin senses.
According to Money, an individual's lovemap develops
almost fully by age eight. "The
development occurs under the
auspices of the same people
who give you your native
language," he stated.
"Unfortunately, we vandalize the normal lovemap
development of children by
conveying the idea that sex is
nasty and dirty," Money
declared. He believes that by
not allowing children to grow
up with intact lovemaps, we are
creating the sexual problems
that plague our society.
"Kids
will
prepare
themselves for normalcy of
development through sexualrehearsal play, if it is not driven
out of them by society,"
Money explained. He noted

that if monkeys are raised in
isolation and deprived of sexual
rehearsal-play, they will never
reproduce when placed with
other members of their species.
Because of the lack of clinics
for sexual development and
sexual problems of children,
parents have nowhere to turn if
things begin to go wrong.
Money criticized this fact as a
result of our "sex-negative
culture."
"We are obsessed v‘ith
criminalizing sex, punishing sex
offenders rather than finding
out what causes the problems,"
he stated. He believes the important issue is to discover why
people grow up with paraphilic
lovemaps. Paraphilia is defined
as a lovemap with distortions or
perversions.
Money discussed the mistaken notion about the connection between paraphilia and
pornography. "Paraphilia is
not contagious, and pornography does not create
paraphilia," he explained.
"The public is afraid that if you

Flood of Freshmen Causes Housing Shortage
CPS—Gary Anderson, a pre-med
freshman at Notre Dame, has
started his college career living
with three other students in a
study lounge "small enough for
just one, really."
Anderson, who gamely adds,
"It's not that bad," is not the
only college student being
wedged into study lounges,
small dorm spaces, single dorm
rooms, and other nooks and
crannies this fall as scores of
campuses nationwide suffer
from an unexpected, though
probably temporary, oncampus housing shortage
again.
The culprit, they say, is an
unanticipated flood of new
freshmen.
So many new freshmen
registered at Emory University
in Atlanta, for example, that
administrators offered upperclassmen $1,000 or a luxury
off-campus apartment if they
agreed to move out of the
dorms.
Duke, Alabama, Florida,
Cal-Davis and, according to
one national campus housing

official, "the great majority"
of colleges across the country
are running out of room to
house students on-campus this
fall.
It wasn't supposed to happen
at all, says James Grubb, president of the Association of College and University Housing
Officers (ACUHO).
"We all looked at shrinking
enrollments through the 1980s
and nineties," he says. Colleges
didn't buy or build new dorms
because "Housing was expected to stay steady or decline
during that period."
Grubb feels colleges simply
have misjudged enrollment
trends, which were supposed to
head downward because there
are fewer 18-year-olds in the
population.
College enrollment did fall
two percent last year, a College
Board census released last week
showed, but it has been steady
through the decade.
Grubb's not sure why some
schools have stayed so crowded. "Although colleges are actively marketing themselves, I

don't think that in itself would
explain the increases in housing
demands."
Freshmen may gravitate
toward dorms for social
reasons. "Students who are
new to the community have no
sense of belonging, no friends
yet," says Alabama housing
chief Tom Strong. Dorms offer
easy ways to develop them.
There are money reasons,
too. "I wouldn't make a
blanket statement that dorm
living is cheaper," Grubb says,
"but it is still a fairly
economical way to live and eat
while you're in school."
Not all college dorms, of
couse, are overcrowded. The
University of Texas at El Paso
closed one of its two dorm
towers this fall.
"We would need about 100
more students to reopen the
tower," says housing director
Becky Baker, who explains
UTEP's large number of commuter students has probably
muted demand for dorm rooms
on campus.
Grubb is "surprised" to hear

of UTEP's decision at a time
when a number of colleges,
finally tired of the dorm shortages that have become a fixture of every fall term, are
debating building new dorms.
At Florida, housing Director
James Grimm thinks there's "a
50/50 chance" UF will build a
new dorm after 10 long years of
overcrowding.
"Right now we've got an
overflow of 400," he says.
"For the first time, we've had
to put students up in the local
Holiday Inn."
Grimm has "been asking for
a new building for ten years
now, and the answer I get is, `11
you can afford it at this bond
interest rate, fine.' Now that
the interest rate is coming back
down again, I've renewed my
request again."
Cal-Davis recently bought
four nearby buildings, remodeled them as-dorms and created
space for 1,224 more oncampus students.
Yet Grimm cautions that
creating more on-campus housing can alienate off-campus

landlords who want to rent to
students.
In Gainesville, "There's a 15
percent vacancy (rate) off campus," says Grimm, who fears
town-gown relations will suffer
if UF finds a way to keep more
students housed on campus
comfortably.
On-campus students may be
the ones who suffer most.
A recent Virginia Polytechnic
study found dorm overcrowding had "no major
academic effect" on students,
but that students generally are
"socially affected" by the uncomfortable living conditions.
Notre Dame's Anderson
says, "It would be great if I got
a real room in this dorm," but
he's not sure how long he could
keep the fragile new friendships
he's begun if the school eventually moves him to a different
building.
"Maybe they shouldn't accept more students than they•
have beds or rooms," Anderson suggests. "We still have our
stuff in suitcases or cardboard
boxes."

The Hopkins News-Letter Japanese Artwork
The Highlight of the Calendar Results in a Furor
Earlier this year, we discussed the recent decline of Intersession and urged
students and faculty alike to begin planning for that informal period of noncompetitive study early. Now that a few
weeks have passed, it's time to consider
a number of specific improvements that
might make Intersession '87 the best yet.
Already, plans have been made to offer eleven new "intensive" courses in
foreign languages and computers. Those
plans are certainly a step in the right
direction. But Intersession needs a nearly
complete overhaul, not just fine tuning
in language and computer course offerings. So, we advance the following
recommendations.
First, the administration needs to dust
off the Intersession Proposal written by
the Committee on Undergraduate
Studies in November, 1984, study it, and
implement the courses of action proposed therein.
To date, exactly one of the numerous
and well-founded recommendations in
the C.U.S. report has been put into effect (namely the addition of special skills
classes in languages and computers
discussed above). The rest of the ideas
have apparently faded away into oblivion. There's still time, however, to blow
life into some of the C.U.S. recommendations, and the University ought to do
so.
To improve the academic nature of Intersession, the C.U.S. report proposes,
among other things, an emphasis on
course offerings in fields that have traditionally been weak at Hopkins. An array of Intersession offerings in areas like
theater, journalism and business would
certainly be an easy way to minimize
Hopkins' shortcomings in these
disciplines and expand the scope of the
Intersession program. Attracting professionals in such fields to teach at Intersession should be a relatively easy endeavor
considering the prominence of many
Hopkins alumni in these diverse areas.
The C.U.S. report also wisely suggests
the expansion of current departmental
offerings to improve the academic nature
of Intersession. Specifically, the report
urges professors to offer survey courses
or seminars in their particular fields of

research—fields which may be too new
or "experimental" to be taught in the
normal undergraduate curriculum. Such
classes would certainly improve the
quality of Intersession as well.
In a discussion on the social shortcomings of Intersession, the report calls for
relaxed organized activities including a
speaker series, one or more film series,
day trips to surrounding points of interest in the mid-Atlantic region, and
faculty/student lunches and dinners.
Unfortunately, all of these worthwhile
recommendations seem to have been
forgotten or shelved indefinitely.
Beyond the C.U.S. proposal, there are
two more fundamental changes that
would ensure a continually strong Intersession program. First, the administration should add Intersession to
the teaching requirements of all newly
hired faculty. A stipulation that each
faculty member must teach at least one
Intersession course every four or five
years in not a particularly demanding or
unreasonable addition to faculty
workloads. Such an addition would, over
time, ensure a supply of top-notch instructors at no additional expense to the
program.
Secondly, all Intersession courses
ought to be offered as part of the standard university curriculum. Payment of
Hopkins' annual tuition should entitle a
student to Intersession classes just as it
entitles a student to take classes during
the regular academic year.
By charging for certain Intersession
courses on a class by class basis (like the
new intensive language and computer
courses) the University is more likely to
turn students away than entice them to
spend their vacations at Hopkins.
It's clear that Intersession needs to be
improved if it is to survive. It's also clear
that the University is falling short in efforts to improve the program. By finally implementing the suggestions proposed in the C.U.S. report two years ago
and making a firm commitment to the
program in terms of faculty and
finances, the University will certainly be
on the road to making Intersession
become what it should be—the highlight
of the academic calendar.

Poster Anarchy
In the aftermath of emotionally charged dramas like the protests and arrests
last week, it's probably natural for a
campus to focus its attentions on matters less weighty. But this week, the talk
around Homewood has changed from
the serious to the down-right silly—
namely, the new "postering policy."
After last week's confrontation,
University President Steven Muller apparently told members of the Coalition
for a Free South Africa that they may
poster on campus wherever they choose.

an unsavory conflict. Unfortunately
though, his authorization destroyed a
reasonably worakble poster policy in ef-

fect for two years.

was to encourage the free exchange of
information in a clean and sightly way.

policy has had a pronounced effect on

To the Editor:

To the Editor:

We are deeply disturbed by
the handling of the Star Trek
Quiz and feel that we can no
longer remain silent.

to get the answers to your quiz,
and for what? Money and time
that could have been spent applying to medical schools
was lost carefully screening
every Star Trek episode we
could lay our tractor beams on.

the His Eminence the Quizmaster: Where the devil are the

universe? Thrown inside the
Doomsday Machine? Suppressed by the Botha regime? Lost in

Constitution!

on the scale of Tabs IV. We request, no... we demand that
the answers are officially logged in next week's News-Letter.

Lack of Foresight
To the Editor:
The recent controversies over
divestment and the University's
shanty policy have been marked by repeated failures to think
actions through with an eye
toward the end results. The
Trustees' policy regarding shanties is a prime example of such

a failure. In August the
Trustees banned shanties. Last
month a court order prohibiting shanties was obtained.
This eventually led to the arrest
of fourteen protestors. The
University then urged the city to
drop charges, and the Trustees
decided to allow shanties on the
lower quad. This sad order of
events points to one of two
possibilities: either the University does not know what to do
or it knows what to do but is
afraid of the consequences.
Whichever is true, it is obvious
that the potential results of the
initial policy were not fully considered by the Trustees.
Also, there is a failure to see
the eventual outcome of permitting protest by construction
project. If the shanties are
allowed then surely the disarmament people could have a devastated village of burnt wood
and twisted steel to protest
nuclear arms and the APL's
work on their delivery systems.
Animal rights activists could
build animal pens and display
rabbits
mistreated
and
monkeys. The shanties are a
precedent and these other
things can surely follow.
A similar absence of
foresight plagues the prodivestment faction. In his
defense of divestment last
week, Thom Kuelhs pointed
out that the Afrikaners are
armed to the teeth and more
than willing to fight it out.
From this terrible fact he concludes that divestment must be
our policy. Yet, it is precisely
because of this fact that we
must restrain ourselves from
emotionally rushing into a
destructive policy. It is true that
the South African situation has
been getting worse, but does
anyone really believe that U.S.
divestment will improve things?
It will not. Instead it will

hasten the coming of civil war.
The end of western and
American influence, as embodied in the Sullivan principles, will leave blacks at the
mercy of Boer reaction rather
than Boers at the mercy of
black revolution. The Coalition
and groups like it should not be
prodding South African blacks
and whites toward the abyss of
race war.
It is amazing that people
associated with this University
could display such a lack of
foresight on these issues. I warn
the Coalition and the Ad- •
ministration that failure to
recognize the eventual consequences of your actions does
not lessen your responsibility
for them.

A History of the Homewood Campus

-by Elizabeth Harrigan
All through your Hopkins
career, you learn more and
more about this campus. As a
pre-frosh, the tour guide explained how Mr. Shriver had
the beauties of Baltimore
painted in the hall that bears his
name.
As a freshman, you ate
doughnuts while celebrating Ira
Remsen's birthday with Drs.
Poland and Aranow as Poland
sang the praises of Remsen's
discovery--saccharin.
And on it goes. However,
there might be some unanswered questions, like "Okay,
so the mansion at the top of the
beach once belonged to Charles
Carroll, but what does that
have to do with Johns
Hopkins?" You might wonder
why Gilman Hall--the heart of
this campus--appears to be such
a self-contained building.
Homewood campus has a
rich history. A few buildings
were built long before the
University was even a twinkle
in Johns Hopkins' eye.
Others were built for the
University's move from its
downtown campus to Homewood; still, these early structures often served a much different purpose then than they
do now.
Early plans show that the
campus was intended to be
much bigger, and in a different
location, than it is now. The
original designers had Johns
Hopkins' own estate, Clifton
(now known as Clifton Park at
the end of 33rd Street), in mind

for the "new" campus. It was
for this reason that 33rd Street
was widened; the gates of the
University were to have opened
onto 33rd. However, by the
time plans actually got underway, Clifton had already been
donated to the city. Now the
only gates opening onto 33rd
are those of Clifton Park.

Homewood, was chosen.
William Keyser, one of' the
University Trustees, owned part
of the land. Samuel Wyman
owned Homewood and was
convinced to sell it to Hopkins.
Between the two, Hopkins acquired a great deal of land. Had
the original planners had their
way, this campus would have
stretched from 29th Street to
University Parkway, and from
Calvert all the way to the
Rotunda. The University later
gave the property south of Art
Museum Drive to the city; it is
now known as Wyman Park.
Much of the property on the
northwest end of campus was
kept as a park.
The bust of Johns Hopkins
located just south of 34th Street
on Charles used to be the
centerpiece of the now nonexistent Hopkins Circle, a traffic
circle in the middle of Charles
right in front of the Homewood
House. The bust was moved in
the 1930's after two fire trucks
tragically collided in the circle.
Take a walk back in time to
the days of Charles Carroll and
watch how Homewood grows
from a country estate into the
home base for one of the nation's premier universities.

Alumni still come back to the
White House to comment
about the difference between it
now and then. The White
House is one of the oldest
buildings on campus and has
been a part of the University
since it was given in 1902 as
part of a land grant.
William Keyser headed the
task of acquiring additional
land for the University to expand upon and the piece of
property from which the White
House originates belonged to
Samuel Wyman.
The specific origin of the
White House prior to that time
is not known. It is suspected
that the White House was built
on a section of land during the
1850's when Wyman was busily constructing his Italian villa
and greenhouse; the White
House could easily have been
constructed at this time.
The White House was first
used as a farmhouse and
through the years has moved its
location three times. Formerly
the White House was located at
the front entrance of the
University but was then
relocated in 1908 for the
residence of the University's
gardener at its present location
beyond Gilman Hall.
Dr. Burford Johnson opened her child institute in 1926,
which was open to the children
of the University faculty and
was in operation for approximately five years. In 1941 the
building was used by the
physical education staff as an
athletic center. The following
year the army commadant's
headquarters were stationed at
the White House. A psychological services clinic was
established in 1943 headed by
Dr. Wilson Shaffer, who for a
time ran the clinic himself. Dr.
Shaffer was later assisted by a
round of twelve part-time
psychologists. The psychological clinic became the
psychiatric clinic in 1963 when
Dr. Ghislaine Godenne took
over the White House.
Today the White House
specializes in counseling and
psychiatry services, employing
seven paid staff and eighteen
mental health volunteers.

The News-Letter wishes to express its appreciation to University Archivist Julie Morgan and
Assistant Archivist Jim
Stitnpert, of the Hamburger
Archives, where the entire
history of the University is
safeguarded for all. In addition, a special thanks goes to
Julie B. Smith of the Office of
News and Information.

The Best Built Dormitory
In the Entire World... • ?
by Isa Santoriello
The
groundbreaking
ceremony on June 12, 1922 for
the first Alumni Memorial
Residence commenced the construction of a dormitory facility that, according to the July
23, 1920 Baltimore Sun, was expected at its completion to be
"the finest equipped of any
university or college in the
country, and possibly in the
world."
Though a committee was appointed to consider the issues of
constructing a dormitory
residence as early as 1910,
serious discussion had not yet
begun when World War I broke
out. After the war, however,
student enrollment increased,
and housing needs became a
critical concern. Simultaneously, university alumni were searching for an appropriate war
memorial to honor Hopkins
men who had been killed in the
war. Conveniently, the decision
to establish the Alumni
Memorial Dormitory took care
of both these concerns.
Funding for the new dormitory was conducted through
an extensive campaign begun
by the Hopkins Alumni
Association, headed by George
L. Radcliffe. The alumni felt
that the dormitory would be-a
living memorial to their
colleagues.
A tablet was erected by the
alumni on the inside left wall as
you enter the dormitory bearing the names of all the
Hopkins men who gave their
lives to their country in the war.
Interestingly enough, however,
when plans to name the

separate houses went into effect
in 1957, the houses were named for famous individuals from
Hopkins' past, instead of for
alumni who had died in the
war, as would seem appropriate. It was the students who
had suggested naming the entrances in this way, thereby
replacing the old and very dull
labels of A,B,C, etc. No one
really knows why the students
did not suggest that the entrances be named for the war
veterans that were killed.
Perhaps the decision was made
on the basis that there were not
enough entrances to honor each
of the 24 alumni that had been
killed.
In any event the new
residence, which was based on
the English system of
"houses," consisted of six
houses, each with its separate
entrance, and a common dining
hall, with kitchen and service
rooms, and also a living or
"commons" room. The object
of the dormitory was said to
have been "to promote good
fellowship and friendliness,
particularly among men of different ages and academic
status, thus regaining some of
the spirit of an English college,
which has been largely lost in
American universities."
Constructed of red brick,
and designed to complement
the other buildings on
Homewood at this time, AMR
I looked, in 1923, much like it
does today. In December of
1983, however, a necessary
renovation changed the
building's interior substantially. The entire building was gutted, and today, beyond the

Aside from the layout, it

in 1923, women were not commonly found in the dormitory

This year the dormitory was

egg encounter by the entry B

great pleasure that a few

For several years, the
Warden of the dormitory was
Dr. John Rath bone Oliver, who
helped to make life in the
dorms comfortable and fun.
Aside from serving as advisor
and confidante to the dorm
residents, Oliver also provided
entertainment. Every week, one
entrance was responsible for
presenting a "talent night,"
and Warden Oliver's ghoulish
tales of well-known murders
was always the most popular
act.
Warden Oliver also served as
the student health clinic in the
old days, taking care of the
residents' pysical needs with a
fist aid kit that he kept by his
door. It is said that his most
regular visitors were the
chemistry students whose
. pranks had literally backfired!
Today, Hopkins dorm life
may be very similar to the way
it was years ago, but the dormitories themselves have certainly changed and expanded.

by Sue Trowbridge
The beauty contest is certainly a subject ripe for satire. It
seems so hopelessly outmoded,
a display of feminine
pulchritude masquerading as a
source of scholarships. If the
pageants for Misses America,
U.S.A., Universe, World, and
all the rest were to disappear
overnight, I wouldn't mourn.
But what female hasn't thought
wistfully at some point, "If only I were pretty enough to be
Miss America..."
"Smile" reflects that
ambiguity—it does satirize the
pageants, but it celebrates them
as well. Sixteen high school
seniors are competing for the title of California's "Young
American Miss"; the winner
will go on to the national finals.
Underneath
the slogan
"Venustas Veritas Est"(beauty is truth), the girls try to impress the judges by being as
vivacious, attractive, and
upstanding as possible. "I want
to be a model and work with
the mentally handicapped!"
squeals one contestant.
The play focuses on Robin
Gibson (Anne Marie Bobby),
Miss Antelope Valley, an intelligent girl who seems to have
stumbled into the pageant by
mistake. In sung asides
("Postcard#1,""#2,""#3"),
Robin confesses her trepidation
at going up against all those
seemingly-perfect young ladies.
She feels even more out of
place when she meets her roommate, Doria Hudson (Jodi Benson), a pageant vet who knows
all the tricks of the trade—put
Vaseline on your teeth so they
don't stick to your lip when you
smile! Glue yout swimsuit to

your hips so it doesn't ride up
when you walk! When Doria
Finds out that Robin's father
died several years ago, she encourages Robin to share that
with the judges. "You can get
orphan points," she says.
Meanwhile, the clean-cut
Freelanders, Brenda and Big
Bob (Marsha Waterbury, Jeff
McCarthy), are there to keep
the girls in line. Brenda won the
statewide "Young American
Miss" title herself several years
ago, but lost at the national
level; now she has another
chance at fame, since the competition's officials have her in
mind for the coveted position
of Pageant Spokeswoman.
Naturally, when the pageant
bigwig (Richard Woods) whom
Brenda must impress arrives,
things start to go wrong.
Among other problems, the
wholesome contest is in danger
of being tainted by scandal—
shades of Vanessa Williams!
"Smile" has plenty of big,
gaudy production numbers and
a catchy score by Marvin
Hamlisch (composer of "A
Chorus Line"). The tongue-incheek "Typical High School
Senior" starts the play with a
bang, as the sixteen contestants
demonstrate that they are
anything but ordinary. "Shine"
is a dynamic dance number,
Featuring Michael O'Gorman in
a hilarious turn as the sleazy,
abrasive pageant choreographer.

really doesn't work is

ballad sung by Doria. She first

Smashing "Squirrels" Opens at Barn Tonight
by Frank H. Wu
The Alex Willis/Barnstormers production of David
Mamet's "Squirrels" is
dominated by Chat Ewing, who
plays a man with a peculiar preoccupation.
Ewing is Arthur, a man not
only obsessed with squirrels,
but also writing a sprawling
metaphysical meditation about
the creatures. He delivers a
powerful performance. His is a
character unhinged, surreal.
With menacing eyebrow
machinations and a terse twang
in his voice, Arthur sits in his
office and proclaims his vision:
"He moves to stroke the squirrel and the squirrel bites his
hand. With his other hand he
grabs the squirrel and squeezes
it until the creature dies." This
opening is only an introduction
to a comic and deranged quest,
that of documenting the
everlasting conflict between
man and squirrel.
Unfortunately, when Arthur
finally gets going with his final
climactic man-squirrel struggle,

he begins to strangle his coconspirator, Edmond (Michael
Runge). As Edmond is responsible for scribbling down all of
Arthur's utterances, the best
prose goes unwritten. And of
course, when Arthur has to
write for himself and his pencil
breaks, he throws himself into
a frenzy: "Can you beat this?
Can you beat this with a large
stick? I think not...I am in the
midst of a sentence, the pencil
sharpener is operating perfectly and the pencil breaks." Arthur is a logician gone mad, using cigarettes to diagram his imaginary battle scenes and
squealing when asked what
relationship his words have to
any meaning or how long he
has been toiling.
Edmond is an apprentice of
sorts and Runge plays the role
well. The dominated, stupid
Edmond could be simply a collection of nervous mannerisms.
But Runge's subtle interpretation suits Edmond's bewildered
and eager to please personality.
As the lesser colleague in this
project of investigating squir-

rels, his primary duty at first is
to take dictation and reply to
Arthur demanding,"Eh?" The
only inconsistency in the performance comes in scenes with
the third , character, the old
cleaning lady (Aimie Hunt).
There, Edmond seems to relax
into sophistication. The worldly
persona looks clumsily donned,
ill-fitting with Edmond's further development, which unfolds nicely.
Asking, "You wanna make
love," Hunt comes across with
a studied, steady depiction of
the old cleaning woman, once
Arthur's lover and possibly Edmond's lover in the future.
Hunt is at her best in this angry
performance when she acts out
the cleaning lady's own deranged little stories. Versatile and
aggressive, she tells of the
Fourth World in the Goolagong
System, with a poisonous atmosphere of Clorox. Although
most of her ranting is more
conventional than the squirrelmongers, the Clorox always
seeps in.
The drama chronicles the

evolution of relationships between these three people,
somehow stuck in this normal
world. With a spartan presentation, director Willis has
evoked a multitude of hilarious
twists in Mamet's work.
Mamet is best known for
"Sexual Perversity in Chicago"
and "Glengarry ,Glen Ross."
Hunt explains that in this play,
he deals with "the process of
creating, When the man finally achieves something, he has to
break away."
The play is brutal and complex. It deals with the artist's
struggle to create, using a complete universe of symbols, from
the actually mundane squirrels
to the Civil War and sexual
politics. To the satisfaction of
the cynical clement, the
.characters are self-aware,
almost ironic. Yet they also
parody introspection, belitt Ii ng
their self-consciousness. Arthur asks, "You ask me about
meaning and I respond with
gibberish. What kind of friend
am I? Are you sure you don't
have a cupcake?" Meanwhile,

Edmond dares to disagree that
Art is Art and the cleaning lady
declares,"You make your own
fun." All of this is presented on
the plot level with the steady
development of the characters,
which perhaps needs clarity in
this production. For all of the
potential hidden implications,
the play is also accessible, thanks
to its completely developed
icons, our friends the squirrels.
The cast and crew are
veterans of the stage at
Hopkins, with the exception of
Carolyn Ewals and she professes
to be "the best stage manager
in the whole world." All in all,
Willis and Company have put
together a drama that is not ordinary fare. The play is witty
and intriguing and the actors
exciting. As Arthur says, there
is more to life than a facility to
use modifiers. This play is a
with
success, certainly
"smashing" as the modifier.
"Squirrels" is opening
tonight at 8:00 p.m. in the
Barn. The technical director is
Andy Angelino.

Scientists Work Towards the Conquest of Pain
by Joseph Gergyes
Now chemicals that are being
synthesized and tested at
Hopkins and research centers
worldwide may potentially help
treat the pain associated with
many common ailments in a
new and economical way.
Such chemicals could be used in the treatment of pain of
cuts, burns, sunburns, headaches, toothaches, arthritis,
angina, colds, and high blood
pressure. Currently, many of
these ailments are treated with
aspirin or in more serious cases
by narcotics, such as codeine.
These drugs, though effective
by dulling the nervous system,
have many side effects, the
most important of which is that
the entire body is depressed.
The new chemicals would work
specifically against the paincausing area. Narcotics can also
be addictive, so physicians are
hesitant to prescribe it on a long
term basis.
The new chemicals can
replace the current painkillers
and hopefully have less serious
side effects. They can be applied to a variety of ailments
because they work to stop the
action of bradykinin, an enzyme of the human nervous
system that is closely associated
with the production of pain.
When the human body is injured, certain enzymes work on
bradykinin to change it from an
inactive to active state.
Bradykinin then prompts the

nerves associated with pain to
fire. Bradykinin also works to
open blood vessels near the site
of the injury so that the white
blood cells that fight infection
will be able to reach the injury
easier. These open blood vessels
are responsible for the inflammation that is often associated
with an injury. The bradykinin
that are in high concentration
around this inflamed area is
what causes the pain one feels
when pressure is applied to an
injury.
John Stewart, a biochemist
from the University of Colorado, has synthesized over 200
chemicals that block bradykinin
from entering active state.
Many of these compounds are
unfortunately very "clumsy"
and "somewhat unstable".
There is also the huge task of
testing the chemicals on
humans and the ethical problems associated with that
testing.
Stewart now has an agreement with Nova Pharmaceuticals, a national company
devoted to the production of
new experimental drugs, to
work towards a drug that can
be used by humans. The immediate goal is to create a
topical painkilling lotion, since
Nova feels such a lotion could
be approved by the FDA.

Johns Hopkins and Robert
Naclerio of the Good Samaritan Hospital in Baltimore are

.has. As every student of introductory psychology soon

shocks. And when our local

Flood of Freshmen Causes Housing Shortage
CPS—Gary Anderson, a pre-med
freshman at Notre Dame, has
started his college career living
with three other students in a
study lounge "small enough for
just one, really."
Anderson, who gamely adds,
"It's not that bad," is not the
only college student being
wedged into study lounges,
small dorm spaces, single dorm
rooms, and other nooks and
crannies this fall as scores of
campuses nationwide suffer
from an unexpected, though
probably temporary, oncampus housing shortage
again.
The culprit, they say, is an
unanticipated flood of new
freshmen.
So many new freshmen
registered at Emory University
in Atlanta, for example, that
administrators offered upperclassmen $1,000 or a luxury
off-campus apartment if they
agreed to move out of the
dorms.
Duke, Alabama, Florida,
Cal-Davis and, according to
one national campus housing

official, "the great majority"
of colleges across the country
are running out of room to
house students on-campus this
fall.
It wasn't supposed to happen
at all, says James Grubb, president of the Association of College and University Housing
Officers (ACUHO).
"We all looked at shrinking
enrollments through the 1980s
and nineties," he says. Colleges
didn't buy or build new dorms
because "Housing was expected to stay steady or decline
during that period."
Grubb feels colleges simply
have misjudged enrollment
trends, which were supposed to
head downward because there
are fewer 18-year-olds in the
population.
College enrollment did fall
two percent last year, a College
Board census released last week
showed, but it has been steady
through the decade.
Grubb's not sure why some
schools have stayed so crowded. "Although colleges are actively marketing themselves, I

don't think that in itself would
explain the increases in housing
demands."
Freshmen may gravitate
toward dorms for social
reasons. "Students who are
new to the community have no
sense of belonging, no friends
yet," says Alabama housing
chief Tom Strong. Dorms offer
easy ways to develop them.
There are money reasons,
too. "I wouldn't make a
blanket statement that dorm
living is cheaper," Grubb says,
"but it is still a fairly
economical way to live and eat
while you're in school."
Not all college dorms, of
couse, are overcrowded. The
University of Texas at El Paso
closed one of its two dorm
towers this fall.
"We would need about 100
more students to reopen the
tower," says housing director
Becky Baker, who explains
UTEP's large number of commuter students has probably
muted demand for dorm rooms
on campus.
Grubb is "surprised" to hear

of UTEP's decision at a time
when a number of colleges,
finally tired of the dorm shortages that have become a fixture of every fall term, are
debating building new dorms.
At Florida, housing Director
James Grimm thinks there's "a
50/50 chance" UF will build a
new dorm after 10 long years of
overcrowding.
"Right now we've got an
overflow of 400," he says.
"For the first time, we've had
to put students up in the local
Holiday Inn."
Grimm has "been asking for
a new building for ten years
now, and the answer I get is, `11
you can afford it at this bond
interest rate, fine.' Now that
the interest rate is coming back
down again, I've renewed my
request again."
Cal-Davis recently bought
four nearby buildings, remodeled them as-dorms and created
space for 1,224 more oncampus students.
Yet Grimm cautions that
creating more on-campus housing can alienate off-campus

landlords who want to rent to
students.
In Gainesville, "There's a 15
percent vacancy (rate) off campus," says Grimm, who fears
town-gown relations will suffer
if UF finds a way to keep more
students housed on campus
comfortably.
On-campus students may be
the ones who suffer most.
A recent Virginia Polytechnic
study found dorm overcrowding had "no major
academic effect" on students,
but that students generally are
"socially affected" by the uncomfortable living conditions.
Notre Dame's Anderson
says, "It would be great if I got
a real room in this dorm," but
he's not sure how long he could
keep the fragile new friendships
he's begun if the school eventually moves him to a different
building.
"Maybe they shouldn't accept more students than they•
have beds or rooms," Anderson suggests. "We still have our
stuff in suitcases or cardboard
boxes."

Earlier this year, we discussed the recent decline of Intersession and urged
students and faculty alike to begin planning for that informal period of noncompetitive study early. Now that a few
weeks have passed, it's time to consider
a number of specific improvements that
might make Intersession '87 the best yet.
Already, plans have been made to offer eleven new "intensive" courses in
foreign languages and computers. Those
plans are certainly a step in the right
direction. But Intersession needs a nearly
complete overhaul, not just fine tuning
in language and computer course offerings. So, we advance the following
recommendations.
First, the administration needs to dust
off the Intersession Proposal written by
the Committee on Undergraduate
Studies in November, 1984, study it, and
implement the courses of action proposed therein.
To date, exactly one of the numerous
and well-founded recommendations in
the C.U.S. report has been put into effect (namely the addition of special skills
classes in languages and computers
discussed above). The rest of the ideas
have apparently faded away into oblivion. There's still time, however, to blow
life into some of the C.U.S. recommendations, and the University ought to do
so.
To improve the academic nature of Intersession, the C.U.S. report proposes,
among other things, an emphasis on
course offerings in fields that have traditionally been weak at Hopkins. An array of Intersession offerings in areas like
theater, journalism and business would
certainly be an easy way to minimize
Hopkins' shortcomings in these
disciplines and expand the scope of the
Intersession program. Attracting professionals in such fields to teach at Intersession should be a relatively easy endeavor
considering the prominence of many
Hopkins alumni in these diverse areas.
The C.U.S. report also wisely suggests
the expansion of current departmental
offerings to improve the academic nature
of Intersession. Specifically, the report
urges professors to offer survey courses
or seminars in their particular fields of

research—fields which may be too new
or "experimental" to be taught in the
normal undergraduate curriculum. Such
classes would certainly improve the
quality of Intersession as well.
In a discussion on the social shortcomings of Intersession, the report calls for
relaxed organized activities including a
speaker series, one or more film series,
day trips to surrounding points of interest in the mid-Atlantic region, and
faculty/student lunches and dinners.
Unfortunately, all of these worthwhile
recommendations seem to have been
forgotten or shelved indefinitely.
Beyond the C.U.S. proposal, there are
two more fundamental changes that
would ensure a continually strong Intersession program. First, the administration should add Intersession to
the teaching requirements of all newly
hired faculty. A stipulation that each
faculty member must teach at least one
Intersession course every four or five
years in not a particularly demanding or
unreasonable addition to faculty
workloads. Such an addition would, over
time, ensure a supply of top-notch instructors at no additional expense to the
program.
Secondly, all Intersession courses
ought to be offered as part of the standard university curriculum. Payment of
Hopkins' annual tuition should entitle a
student to Intersession classes just as it
entitles a student to take classes during
the regular academic year.
By charging for certain Intersession
courses on a class by class basis (like the
new intensive language and computer
courses) the University is more likely to
turn students away than entice them to
spend their vacations at Hopkins.
It's clear that Intersession needs to be
improved if it is to survive. It's also clear
that the University is falling short in efforts to improve the program. By finally implementing the suggestions proposed in the C.U.S. report two years ago
and making a firm commitment to the
program in terms of faculty and
finances, the University will certainly be
on the road to making Intersession
become what it should be—the highlight
of the academic calendar.

of fourteen protestors. The

drop charges, and the Trustees
decided to allow shanties on the
lower quad. This sad order of
events points to one of two
possibilities: either the University does not know what to do

afraid of the consequences.

initial policy were not fully considered by the Trustees.

rabbits
mistreated
and

precedent and these other
things can surely follow.

foresight plagues the prodivestment faction. In his

week, Thom Kuelhs pointed
out that the Afrikaners are

for this reason that 33rd Street

Alumni still come back to the
White House to comment
about the difference between it
now and then. The White
House is one of the oldest
buildings on campus and has
been a part of the University
since it was given in 1902 as
part of a land grant.
William Keyser headed the
task of acquiring additional
land for the University to expand upon and the piece of
property from which the White
House originates belonged to
Samuel Wyman.
The specific origin of the
White House prior to that time
is not known. It is suspected
that the White House was built
on a section of land during the
1850's when Wyman was busily constructing his Italian villa
and greenhouse; the White
House could easily have been
constructed at this time.
The White House was first
used as a farmhouse and
through the years has moved its
location three times. Formerly
the White House was located at
the front entrance of the
University but was then
relocated in 1908 for the
residence of the University's
gardener at its present location
beyond Gilman Hall.
Dr. Burford Johnson opened her child institute in 1926,
which was open to the children
of the University faculty and
was in operation for approximately five years. In 1941 the
building was used by the
physical education staff as an
athletic center. The following
year the army commadant's
headquarters were stationed at
the White House. A psychological services clinic was
established in 1943 headed by
Dr. Wilson Shaffer, who for a
time ran the clinic himself. Dr.
Shaffer was later assisted by a
round of twelve part-time
psychologists. The psychological clinic became the
psychiatric clinic in 1963 when
Dr. Ghislaine Godenne took
over the White House.
Today the White House
specializes in counseling and
psychiatry services, employing
seven paid staff and eighteen
mental health volunteers.

The News-Letter wishes to express its appreciation to University Archivist Julie Morgan and
Assistant Archivist Jim
Stitnpert, of the Hamburger
Archives, where the entire
history of the University is
safeguarded for all. In addition, a special thanks goes to
Julie B. Smith of the Office of
News and Information.

The Best Built Dormitory
In the Entire World... • ?
by Isa Santoriello
The
groundbreaking
ceremony on June 12, 1922 for
the first Alumni Memorial
Residence commenced the construction of a dormitory facility that, according to the July
23, 1920 Baltimore Sun, was expected at its completion to be
"the finest equipped of any
university or college in the
country, and possibly in the
world."
Though a committee was appointed to consider the issues of
constructing a dormitory
residence as early as 1910,
serious discussion had not yet
begun when World War I broke
out. After the war, however,
student enrollment increased,
and housing needs became a
critical concern. Simultaneously, university alumni were searching for an appropriate war
memorial to honor Hopkins
men who had been killed in the
war. Conveniently, the decision
to establish the Alumni
Memorial Dormitory took care
of both these concerns.
Funding for the new dormitory was conducted through
an extensive campaign begun
by the Hopkins Alumni
Association, headed by George
L. Radcliffe. The alumni felt
that the dormitory would be-a
living memorial to their
colleagues.
A tablet was erected by the
alumni on the inside left wall as
you enter the dormitory bearing the names of all the
Hopkins men who gave their
lives to their country in the war.
Interestingly enough, however,
when plans to name the

separate houses went into effect
in 1957, the houses were named for famous individuals from
Hopkins' past, instead of for
alumni who had died in the
war, as would seem appropriate. It was the students who
had suggested naming the entrances in this way, thereby
replacing the old and very dull
labels of A,B,C, etc. No one
really knows why the students
did not suggest that the entrances be named for the war
veterans that were killed.
Perhaps the decision was made
on the basis that there were not
enough entrances to honor each
of the 24 alumni that had been
killed.
In any event the new
residence, which was based on
the English system of
"houses," consisted of six
houses, each with its separate
entrance, and a common dining
hall, with kitchen and service
rooms, and also a living or
"commons" room. The object
of the dormitory was said to
have been "to promote good
fellowship and friendliness,
particularly among men of different ages and academic
status, thus regaining some of
the spirit of an English college,
which has been largely lost in
American universities."
Constructed of red brick,
and designed to complement
the other buildings on
Homewood at this time, AMR
I looked, in 1923, much like it
does today. In December of
1983, however, a necessary
renovation changed the
building's interior substantially. The entire building was gutted, and today, beyond the

The patio outside was also

new stone, but the courtyard
was changed only slightly.
Aside from the layout, it
seems that the only other mentionable difference between the
dormitory as it was in 1923 to
they way it is at present is that
in 1923, women were not commonly found in the dormitory
at all. Indeed, without special
permission from the warden or
managress (the equivalent of
today's Director of Residential
Life), women, along with pets,
were strictly forbidden in any of
the dormitory rooms. But
residents were free to stay out

This year the dormitory was

has been in previous years...An
egg encounter by the entry B
boys appropriately opened the

great pleasure that a few

For several years, the
Warden of the dormitory was
Dr. John Rath bone Oliver, who
helped to make life in the

Aside from serving as advisor
and confidante to the dorm
residents, Oliver also provided
entertainment. Every week, one
entrance was responsible for
presenting a "talent night,"
and Warden Oliver's ghoulish
tales of well-known murders
was always the most popular
act.
Warden Oliver also served as
the student health clinic in the
old days, taking care of the
residents' pysical needs with a
fist aid kit that he kept by his
door. It is said that his most
regular visitors were the
chemistry students whose
. pranks had literally backfired!
Today, Hopkins dorm life
may be very similar to the way
it was years ago, but the dormitories themselves have certainly changed and expanded.

there is AMR II, built in 1953
and referred to as "cinderblock
cells" though they were designed with careful planning; there

Smashing "Squirrels" Opens at Barn Tonight
by Frank H. Wu
The Alex Willis/Barnstormers production of David
Mamet's "Squirrels" is
dominated by Chat Ewing, who
plays a man with a peculiar preoccupation.
Ewing is Arthur, a man not
only obsessed with squirrels,
but also writing a sprawling
metaphysical meditation about
the creatures. He delivers a
powerful performance. His is a
character unhinged, surreal.
With menacing eyebrow
machinations and a terse twang
in his voice, Arthur sits in his
office and proclaims his vision:
"He moves to stroke the squirrel and the squirrel bites his
hand. With his other hand he
grabs the squirrel and squeezes
it until the creature dies." This
opening is only an introduction
to a comic and deranged quest,
that of documenting the
everlasting conflict between
man and squirrel.
Unfortunately, when Arthur
finally gets going with his final
climactic man-squirrel struggle,

he begins to strangle his coconspirator, Edmond (Michael
Runge). As Edmond is responsible for scribbling down all of
Arthur's utterances, the best
prose goes unwritten. And of
course, when Arthur has to
write for himself and his pencil
breaks, he throws himself into
a frenzy: "Can you beat this?
Can you beat this with a large
stick? I think not...I am in the
midst of a sentence, the pencil
sharpener is operating perfectly and the pencil breaks." Arthur is a logician gone mad, using cigarettes to diagram his imaginary battle scenes and
squealing when asked what
relationship his words have to
any meaning or how long he
has been toiling.
Edmond is an apprentice of
sorts and Runge plays the role
well. The dominated, stupid
Edmond could be simply a collection of nervous mannerisms.
But Runge's subtle interpretation suits Edmond's bewildered
and eager to please personality.
As the lesser colleague in this
project of investigating squir-

rels, his primary duty at first is
to take dictation and reply to
Arthur demanding,"Eh?" The
only inconsistency in the performance comes in scenes with
the third , character, the old
cleaning lady (Aimie Hunt).
There, Edmond seems to relax
into sophistication. The worldly
persona looks clumsily donned,
ill-fitting with Edmond's further development, which unfolds nicely.
Asking, "You wanna make
love," Hunt comes across with
a studied, steady depiction of
the old cleaning woman, once
Arthur's lover and possibly Edmond's lover in the future.
Hunt is at her best in this angry
performance when she acts out
the cleaning lady's own deranged little stories. Versatile and
aggressive, she tells of the
Fourth World in the Goolagong
System, with a poisonous atmosphere of Clorox. Although
most of her ranting is more
conventional than the squirrelmongers, the Clorox always
seeps in.
The drama chronicles the

evolution of relationships between these three people,
somehow stuck in this normal
world. With a spartan presentation, director Willis has
evoked a multitude of hilarious
twists in Mamet's work.
Mamet is best known for
"Sexual Perversity in Chicago"
and "Glengarry ,Glen Ross."
Hunt explains that in this play,
he deals with "the process of
creating, When the man finally achieves something, he has to
break away."
The play is brutal and complex. It deals with the artist's
struggle to create, using a complete universe of symbols, from
the actually mundane squirrels
to the Civil War and sexual
politics. To the satisfaction of
the cynical clement, the
.characters are self-aware,
almost ironic. Yet they also
parody introspection, belitt Ii ng
their self-consciousness. Arthur asks, "You ask me about
meaning and I respond with
gibberish. What kind of friend
am I? Are you sure you don't
have a cupcake?" Meanwhile,

Edmond dares to disagree that
Art is Art and the cleaning lady
declares,"You make your own
fun." All of this is presented on
the plot level with the steady
development of the characters,
which perhaps needs clarity in
this production. For all of the
potential hidden implications,
the play is also accessible, thanks
to its completely developed
icons, our friends the squirrels.
The cast and crew are
veterans of the stage at
Hopkins, with the exception of
Carolyn Ewals and she professes
to be "the best stage manager
in the whole world." All in all,
Willis and Company have put
together a drama that is not ordinary fare. The play is witty
and intriguing and the actors
exciting. As Arthur says, there
is more to life than a facility to
use modifiers. This play is a
with
success, certainly

Scientists Work Towards the Conquest of Pain
by Joseph Gergyes
Now chemicals that are being
synthesized and tested at
Hopkins and research centers
worldwide may potentially help
treat the pain associated with
many common ailments in a
new and economical way.
Such chemicals could be used in the treatment of pain of
cuts, burns, sunburns, headaches, toothaches, arthritis,
angina, colds, and high blood
pressure. Currently, many of
these ailments are treated with
aspirin or in more serious cases
by narcotics, such as codeine.
These drugs, though effective
by dulling the nervous system,
have many side effects, the
most important of which is that
the entire body is depressed.
The new chemicals would work
specifically against the paincausing area. Narcotics can also
be addictive, so physicians are
hesitant to prescribe it on a long
term basis.
The new chemicals can
replace the current painkillers
and hopefully have less serious
side effects. They can be applied to a variety of ailments
because they work to stop the
action of bradykinin, an enzyme of the human nervous
system that is closely associated
with the production of pain.
When the human body is injured, certain enzymes work on
bradykinin to change it from an
inactive to active state.
Bradykinin then prompts the

nerves associated with pain to
fire. Bradykinin also works to
open blood vessels near the site
of the injury so that the white
blood cells that fight infection
will be able to reach the injury
easier. These open blood vessels
are responsible for the inflammation that is often associated
with an injury. The bradykinin
that are in high concentration
around this inflamed area is
what causes the pain one feels
when pressure is applied to an
injury.
John Stewart, a biochemist
from the University of Colorado, has synthesized over 200
chemicals that block bradykinin
from entering active state.
Many of these compounds are
unfortunately very "clumsy"
and "somewhat unstable".
There is also the huge task of
testing the chemicals on
humans and the ethical problems associated with that
testing.
Stewart now has an agreement with Nova Pharmaceuticals, a national company
devoted to the production of
new experimental drugs, to
work towards a drug that can
be used by humans. The immediate goal is to create a
topical painkilling lotion, since
Nova feels such a lotion could
be approved by the FDA.

Johns Hopkins and Robert
Naclerio of the Good Samaritan Hospital in Baltimore are
